text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.

6-Nate English from the BBC.
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English,
the show that brings you an interesting topic,
authentic listening practice and six new items of vocabulary.
I'm Dan.
Neil
speaker: bio-sensor

text: …And I'm Neil. We’ll be discussing dogs being used in cancer detection.
speaker: Neil

text: Everything okay, Neil?
Oh, I'm so tired.
One of my children is a sick as a dog.
I didn't sleep all night long looking after them.
As sick as a dog is an expression meaning ‘very ill’. I’m sorry to hear it. Try and hold on if you can.
speaker: As sick as a dog

text: I'm sorry to hear it.
Try and hold on if you can.
Don't worry.
There's life in this whole dog yet.
Good.
It's funny that you mentioned dogs because the UK's
National Health Service is currently assessing where the dogs
can be used to detect early stage prostate cancer.
Amazing.
Amazing. Any success?
speaker: Neil

text: Let me ask you in this week's question.
Oh yes. I asked you in what percentage of cases were dogs able to detect the presence of cancer in urine?
speaker: Dan

text: the presence of cancer in urine?
I’m going to guess a) 50%
speaker: Neil

text: We’ll find out later if you’re right or wrong. So, Neil, I say dog, what do you think?
speaker: Dan

text: So, Neil, I say dog, what do you think?
A wet nose, four paws, which is what we call the feet of certain animals.
Fluffy coat and a waggy tail, man's best friend.
But I've never heard of cancer dogs.
I wonder what makes them suitable.
Well, I’ll let Dr Claire Guest, CEO of the charity Medical Detection Dogs take that one.
speaker: Dan

text: Although the dog has a fluffy coat and a waggy tail, he is in fact a highly sophisticated
biosensor.
You know, evolution is given in this highly sensitive nose.
Go down to parts of the trillions.
People bore planes every day.
There have been screened by detected dogs to see if they're exposed to some board.
Why do we rely on them now and yet not in the systems with help?
So, dogs have evolved to have a highly developed sense of smell that allows them to act as a biosensor,
a sensor which uses a living thing to detect chemicals.
Yes, and she mentioned that humans have a history of using dogs in security to screen, or examine for suitability, for explosives and bombs.
speaker: screen

text: to screen or examine for suitability, for explosives and bombs.
Yep.
Yep! Can you think of any other places that dogs are used to support humans?
speaker: Dan

text: Well, there's guide dogs or seeing eye dogs as they're known in North America.
They help people who are blind to avoid danger.
Nice.
Any more?
Nice. Any more? Maybe around the home?
speaker: Dan

text: Are you referring to guard dogs, meaning ‘a dog which keeps a house or place safe from burglary, theft or trespassing.’
speaker: Neil

text: theft or trespassing?
Yep.
X burglars have often said that there are much bigger deterrent or reason not to do something
than an alarm system.
Oh, and there's rescue dogs.
They're trained to search and find victims of natural disasters,
such as avalanches or earthquakes.
Exactly.
Exactly, dogs are perfect for situations where people may be buried under the earth or the snow. A human can’t see them but a dog can still smell them.
speaker: Dan

text: A human can't see them, but a dog can still smell them.
Do you think our national health service will employ them as full-time biosensors, then?
Well, I don’t know, but here’s what Jeremy Hunt, the UK Health Secretary had to say on the matter.
speaker: Dan

text: One of our jobs as MPs is sometimes to question orthodoxies,
One of our jobs as MPs is sometimes to question orthodoxies, so if this research is good then I want to know about it, and I will certainly look at it carefully.
speaker: orthodoxies

text: He mentions that this type of research goes against orthodoxies or generally accepted ways of
doing things, but he also mentions that he will be looking at it carefully.
So let's hope so.
Yes, I wouldn't mind having a dog doctor.
Yes I wouldn’t mind having a dog doctor! And speaking of research, there was a question I need to know the answer to.
speaker: Neil

text: Oh, yes.
I asked you in what percentage of cases were dogs able to detect the presence of cancer in urine?
And I said 50%
speaker: Neil

text: It’s a dog’s life, Neil. I’m sorry. The answer was c) 90%
speaker: Dan

text: The answer was C, 90%.
That's amazing, isn't it?
Shall we go through the vocabulary?
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, the first expression we had was as sick as a dog.
If you are as sick as a dog, it means that you're very sick indeed.
When was the last time you were as sick as a dog, Neil?
Oh, just after Christmas, I caught a bug from my kids.
Oh, I was as sick as a dog.
Next, we had paws.
Paws are the feet of certain animals.
They have pads and claws.
Can you give us a few examples, Dan?
Well, dogs have paws, so do cats, rabbits, bears, and mice.
But not horses, sheep, or pigs, they have hooves.
After paws, we had biosensor.
A biosensor is a combination of the words biology and sensor.
It is a sensor which uses a living thing to detect chemicals.
Can you think of a famous historical example, Neil?
Well, miners in danger of highly toxic but invisible gas,
called methane, used to carry a canary and a cage down the mine with them.
If the canary became ill or died, they knew the air was toxic.
Then we had screen.
If you screen something, it means you examine it for its suitability,
such as luggage going through an airport,
where they would screen for explosives.
How else can it be used, Dan?
Well, these days you can get an ad block on your computer
that will screen out those annoying pop-up adverts.
I hate those.
After that was deterrent.
A deterrent is a thing which stops a person from doing something,
such as the fear of punishment for a crime.
How do you deter your children for being naughty, Neil?
Oh, that's easy.
I just threatened to remove a sticker from their sticker charts.
Good idea!
speaker: Dan

text: Finally, we heard orthodoxies.
An orthodoxy is a generally accepted way of doing things.
Its adjective is orthodox, and we often hear its opposite word,
unorthodox, meaning unusual.
Do you do anything unorthodox, Dan?
Well, I love to combine hot sausages and cold vanilla ice cream.
It's delicious, but no one will trust me enough to try.
Well, I don't blame them.
I don’t blame them! Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!
speaker: Neil

text: Please join us again soon.
And we're on social media too.
Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.
See you there.
Goodbye.
Bye!
